content.description: A software company provides specialized resort reservation software that can be tailored to the needs of its customers. The companyâ€™s 120 customers pay yearly subscription costs that can vary from customer to customer. The company knows that to be profitable, it needs each customer to be spending at least $23,000 per year, on average. The company selects a random sample of 33 customers and computes a mean of $27,871 and a standard deviation of $309.10. It performs a hypothesis test and computes a very small <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value. The software company concludes that the mean is greater than $23,000.
content.question: Was it appropriate for the software company to perform the hypothesis test and make the conclusion that was made?

choices.label: Yes, because the <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is very small, so the company has sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis and conclude that its customers are spending more, on average, than $23,000 per year.
